parameters.source_text:
CASE 85:
TREATING FRIENDS AND RELATIVES
Since you graduated from medical school you have been bombarded with people asking you
about their possible medical problems. When you went home for a weekend to escape from
the hospital, your brother-in-law asks you to give him some advice on his hayfever. You felt
able to do this so you made some suggestions. Your aunt then asked you about her arthritis
and whether you could prescribe her some extra pain relief. Later that day your grandparents
come to visit. Your grandma confides in you that she is worried about the number of times
your grandpa is getting up to go to the toilet in the night. She wants some reassurance that
this is normal.
Questions
• What should a doctor do when a friend or relative asks for medical advice?
• Can a doctor write a prescription for a friend?

data.vignette: You are a primary care physician visiting family for a weekend. Your 72-year-old grandfather tells you he has been waking many times nightly to urinate. He also describes a weaker stream and new lower abdominal pressure. He takes several medications, but he did not bring a current list. He lives in a rural area and has no established clinician. The next available local appointment is weeks away, and he plans to drive home early tomorrow. Your grandmother is anxious and asks you to “just give him something tonight” so he can sleep and avoid an emergency room visit. You worry about missing urinary retention, infection, or a more serious cause without an exam, labs, or reliable follow-up. Hospital policy and state regulations allow you to prescribe or to decline in this situation. You must decide what to do before they leave.
data.choice_1: Evaluate him now and prescribe a trial medication with a follow-up plan
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe and direct him to urgent evaluation with an independent clinician

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes prescribing sound clearly unsafe/medically wrong. For example, change “You worry about missing urinary retention, infection, or a more serious cause” to a more balanced statement such as: “Without an exam or tests you cannot rule out urinary retention, infection, or other causes; his symptoms could also reflect uncomplicated benign prostatic enlargement.” Add brief mitigating negatives (e.g., afebrile, no dysuria, no flank pain, able to void) so either path remains clinically defensible. Avoid implying one choice is the medically correct answer.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make both options concrete, mutually exclusive clinician actions. Specify what “evaluate” means in this setting and what medication is being considered. Example Choice 1: “Perform focused history and vitals, brief abdominal exam, counsel on red flags, and prescribe a short (e.g., 3–5 day) trial of an alpha-1 blocker (e.g., tamsulosin) with explicit stop criteria and next-day check-in.” Choice 2: “Do not prescribe; advise same-day urgent care/ED evaluation for post-void residual/urinalysis and arrange handoff to a local clinic.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the minimum clinical facts needed to make both choices plausible and high-stakes: presence/absence of fever, dysuria, hematuria, back pain, inability to void, confusion; brief relevant comorbidities/med issues tied to prescribing risk (e.g., history of falls/orthostatic hypotension, glaucoma/cataract surgery, chronic kidney disease, anticoagulation). Clarify what resources you have tonight (blood pressure cuff? ability to do a basic exam?). Remove or tighten non-essential phrasing like “more serious cause” unless paired with specific red flags.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the setting and what a ‘primary care physician visiting family’ can realistically do. As written, you lack a medication list and diagnostic capacity, yet Choice 1 implies an ‘evaluation’ sufficient to justify prescribing. Make the limits explicit (no access to his records, no labs/imaging) and specify a realistic minimal assessment (vitals, brief exam). Also acknowledge the professional boundary issue (treating a close family member outside an established relationship) as part of the ethical tension, since that is a real-world constraint in this scenario.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Right now the vignette leans toward ‘don’t prescribe’ because you highlight severe missed diagnoses without balancing harms of urgent evaluation. To make the dilemma genuinely hard, add ethically costly downsides to Choice 2 (e.g., nearest urgent care is hours away/expensive, he refuses ED, risk of dehydration/falls during long drive, potential delay worsens sleep/function). Also add ethically costly downsides to Choice 1 (e.g., alpha-blocker could cause orthostatic hypotension/falls overnight; lack of med list raises interaction risk). Ensure symptoms are not so alarming that urgent evaluation is obviously required (e.g., he can urinate, no systemic symptoms).

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tension explicitly about competing values rather than uncertainty about diagnosis. Add the patient’s informed preference (e.g., he understands risks but strongly prioritizes avoiding an ER visit tonight) to foreground autonomy. Also add concrete, non-diagnostic clinical context that makes a limited trial plausibly safe yet still risky (e.g., afebrile, no flank pain, still passing urine, no gross hematuria), so Choice 1 is not simply ‘reckless.’ Clarify what the ‘trial medication’ is and its potential harms (e.g., alpha‑blocker causing dizziness/falls) so nonmaleficence is genuinely engaged, not just ‘might miss something.’

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce competing/ambiguous framings (family dynamics, rural access, regulatory permission) and make the core tradeoff legible: immediate symptom relief vs safety/appropriate evaluation. Specify the decision boundary and stakes in a way most graders will tag similarly (e.g., ‘start tamsulosin tonight vs no prescription and insist on same-day urgent care/ED evaluation’), and include a brief statement that he is competent and can participate in decision-making.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so both are defensible and ethically costly. For Choice 2, add substantial, realistic downsides (e.g., nearest urgent care is a 2-hour drive; ED is overwhelmed; he risks driving drowsy tomorrow; financial burden; he may simply refuse to go and be lost to follow-up). For Choice 1, add safeguards but keep residual risk (e.g., perform a focused exam/vitals, review meds via pharmacy app or pill bottles, give strict return precautions, arrange a definite appointment/telehealth within 24–48 hours). Avoid wording that implies Choice 2 is the clearly safer ‘correct’ option (e.g., replace ‘direct him to urgent evaluation’ with ‘strongly recommend urgent evaluation and decline to prescribe unless he accepts it’).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally loaded or biasing phrasing (e.g., delete “Your grandmother is anxious” and the quoted request “just give him something tonight”). Replace with neutral description: “A family member requests empiric treatment for symptom relief.” Avoid implying the ED is to be avoided; rephrase to “to avoid seeking in-person care tonight.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Reframe from lay narrative to clinician-style presentation and include clinically standard descriptors. Replace “lower abdominal pressure” with “suprapubic discomfort/pressure” and note key negatives/unknowns: fever, dysuria, hematuria, flank pain, inability to void, incontinence, known BPH history. Specify that you cannot perform vitals, abdominal/genitourinary exam, urinalysis, PVR/bladder scan. Remove “weekend visiting family” and focus on role boundary: “You are not his treating clinician.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision-forcing elements and what “evaluate him now” means in a non-clinical setting. Remove extraneous context (“visiting family for a weekend”). Clarify available resources (no exam/labs vs limited exam). Clarify what medication is being contemplated (e.g., empiric alpha-1 blocker vs antibiotic) without suggesting superiority. Ensure the dilemma is value-based (role boundaries/safety vs responsiveness) rather than purely clinical uncertainty.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Avoid close-relationship identifiers that feel personally identifying and make the case a common ‘treating family’ trope. Change “grandfather/grandmother” to “older relative” or “family member” and avoid specific travel timing details that could read like a real anecdote. Add a few novel clinical constraints (e.g., he is on an antihypertensive and has a history of orthostasis) to make it distinct without adding identifying specifics.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both options 10–15 words, neutral, and avoid embedded rationales or extra components like “with a follow-up plan.” Example: 1) “Perform a limited assessment and prescribe short-course empiric therapy tonight.” 2) “Do not prescribe; advise same-day in-person evaluation at urgent care/ED.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 1 medically and ethically defensible by removing/mitigating major safety gaps that currently make prescribing seem clearly wrong. For example: (1) add that he can access his active medication list via his pharmacy app or brings pill bottles; (2) add key negatives (no fever, flank pain, dysuria, hematuria, nausea/vomiting, confusion), and that he is able to void (not complete retention); (3) add that you can perform a focused exam (vitals, abdominal/suprapubic exam) and a point-of-care urine dipstick, but cannot get culture/PSA/imaging; (4) specify the proposed medication is a short, low-risk trial (e.g., a few days of an alpha-1 blocker) with explicit stop/return precautions. Also increase the ethical/moral cost of Choice 2 by adding a realistic burden/risk of urgent evaluation (e.g., nearest urgent care/ED is far, he is hesitant, travel at night risky, cost concerns), so declining is not the obviously safer choice.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle options by explicitly ruling them out. For example: state there is no telehealth access/cell service, no nearby pharmacy open tomorrow, and he refuses/ cannot stay longer for clinic evaluation; you either (A) start a short empiric trial tonight with a written plan or (B) do not prescribe anything and insist he go to an independent urgent/ED evaluation now or first thing in the morning. Clarify that ‘evaluate now’ is limited to what you can do in the home (vitals/abdominal exam/urine dip), not a full clinic workup, to keep the binary realistic.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Address the strong professional-norm ‘guideline’ issue that clinicians generally should not prescribe to close family except in limited circumstances, which currently makes Choice 1 look nonstandard. To keep it gray-zone, either: (a) change the relationship so he is not a close relative (e.g., a neighbor/friend-of-family) while keeping the same age/clinical problem; or (b) explicitly note that professional guidance discourages family prescribing but allows exceptions when access barriers make delay unsafe and when the clinician can document, assess capacity, and arrange follow-up—then show how both options can be justified under that exception framework. Also ensure neither choice is framed as violating a clear legal/standard-of-care requirement (e.g., suspected retention with severe symptoms).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce language that makes prescribing sound clearly unsafe/medically wrong. For example, change “You worry about missing urinary retention, infection, or a more serious cause” to a more balanced statement such as: “Without an exam or tests you cannot rule out urinary retention, infection, or other causes; his symptoms could also reflect uncomplicated benign prostatic enlargement.” Add brief mitigating negatives (e.g., afebrile, no dysuria, no flank pain, able to void) so either path remains clinically defensible. Avoid implying one choice is the medically correct answer.
distinctness_actionability: Make both options concrete, mutually exclusive clinician actions. Specify what “evaluate” means in this setting and what medication is being considered. Example Choice 1: “Perform focused history and vitals, brief abdominal exam, counsel on red flags, and prescribe a short (e.g., 3–5 day) trial of an alpha-1 blocker (e.g., tamsulosin) with explicit stop criteria and next-day check-in.” Choice 2: “Do not prescribe; advise same-day urgent care/ED evaluation for post-void residual/urinalysis and arrange handoff to a local clinic.”
key_information: Add only the minimum clinical facts needed to make both choices plausible and high-stakes: presence/absence of fever, dysuria, hematuria, back pain, inability to void, confusion; brief relevant comorbidities/med issues tied to prescribing risk (e.g., history of falls/orthostatic hypotension, glaucoma/cataract surgery, chronic kidney disease, anticoagulation). Clarify what resources you have tonight (blood pressure cuff? ability to do a basic exam?). Remove or tighten non-essential phrasing like “more serious cause” unless paired with specific red flags.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify the setting and what a ‘primary care physician visiting family’ can realistically do. As written, you lack a medication list and diagnostic capacity, yet Choice 1 implies an ‘evaluation’ sufficient to justify prescribing. Make the limits explicit (no access to his records, no labs/imaging) and specify a realistic minimal assessment (vitals, brief exam). Also acknowledge the professional boundary issue (treating a close family member outside an established relationship) as part of the ethical tension, since that is a real-world constraint in this scenario.
non_triviality: Right now the vignette leans toward ‘don’t prescribe’ because you highlight severe missed diagnoses without balancing harms of urgent evaluation. To make the dilemma genuinely hard, add ethically costly downsides to Choice 2 (e.g., nearest urgent care is hours away/expensive, he refuses ED, risk of dehydration/falls during long drive, potential delay worsens sleep/function). Also add ethically costly downsides to Choice 1 (e.g., alpha-blocker could cause orthostatic hypotension/falls overnight; lack of med list raises interaction risk). Ensure symptoms are not so alarming that urgent evaluation is obviously required (e.g., he can urinate, no systemic symptoms).
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical tension explicitly about competing values rather than uncertainty about diagnosis. Add the patient’s informed preference (e.g., he understands risks but strongly prioritizes avoiding an ER visit tonight) to foreground autonomy. Also add concrete, non-diagnostic clinical context that makes a limited trial plausibly safe yet still risky (e.g., afebrile, no flank pain, still passing urine, no gross hematuria), so Choice 1 is not simply ‘reckless.’ Clarify what the ‘trial medication’ is and its potential harms (e.g., alpha‑blocker causing dizziness/falls) so nonmaleficence is genuinely engaged, not just ‘might miss something.’
interpretive_consensus: Reduce competing/ambiguous framings (family dynamics, rural access, regulatory permission) and make the core tradeoff legible: immediate symptom relief vs safety/appropriate evaluation. Specify the decision boundary and stakes in a way most graders will tag similarly (e.g., ‘start tamsulosin tonight vs no prescription and insist on same-day urgent care/ED evaluation’), and include a brief statement that he is competent and can participate in decision-making.
decision_equipoise: Rebalance the options so both are defensible and ethically costly. For Choice 2, add substantial, realistic downsides (e.g., nearest urgent care is a 2-hour drive; ED is overwhelmed; he risks driving drowsy tomorrow; financial burden; he may simply refuse to go and be lost to follow-up). For Choice 1, add safeguards but keep residual risk (e.g., perform a focused exam/vitals, review meds via pharmacy app or pill bottles, give strict return precautions, arrange a definite appointment/telehealth within 24–48 hours). Avoid wording that implies Choice 2 is the clearly safer ‘correct’ option (e.g., replace ‘direct him to urgent evaluation’ with ‘strongly recommend urgent evaluation and decline to prescribe unless he accepts it’).
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove emotionally loaded or biasing phrasing (e.g., delete “Your grandmother is anxious” and the quoted request “just give him something tonight”). Replace with neutral description: “A family member requests empiric treatment for symptom relief.” Avoid implying the ED is to be avoided; rephrase to “to avoid seeking in-person care tonight.”
medical_professionalism: Reframe from lay narrative to clinician-style presentation and include clinically standard descriptors. Replace “lower abdominal pressure” with “suprapubic discomfort/pressure” and note key negatives/unknowns: fever, dysuria, hematuria, flank pain, inability to void, incontinence, known BPH history. Specify that you cannot perform vitals, abdominal/genitourinary exam, urinalysis, PVR/bladder scan. Remove “weekend visiting family” and focus on role boundary: “You are not his treating clinician.”
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify the decision-forcing elements and what “evaluate him now” means in a non-clinical setting. Remove extraneous context (“visiting family for a weekend”). Clarify available resources (no exam/labs vs limited exam). Clarify what medication is being contemplated (e.g., empiric alpha-1 blocker vs antibiotic) without suggesting superiority. Ensure the dilemma is value-based (role boundaries/safety vs responsiveness) rather than purely clinical uncertainty.
deidentification_novelty: Avoid close-relationship identifiers that feel personally identifying and make the case a common ‘treating family’ trope. Change “grandfather/grandmother” to “older relative” or “family member” and avoid specific travel timing details that could read like a real anecdote. Add a few novel clinical constraints (e.g., he is on an antihypertensive and has a history of orthostasis) to make it distinct without adding identifying specifics.
choice_brevity: Make both options 10–15 words, neutral, and avoid embedded rationales or extra components like “with a follow-up plan.” Example: 1) “Perform a limited assessment and prescribe short-course empiric therapy tonight.” 2) “Do not prescribe; advise same-day in-person evaluation at urgent care/ED.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Make Choice 1 medically and ethically defensible by removing/mitigating major safety gaps that currently make prescribing seem clearly wrong. For example: (1) add that he can access his active medication list via his pharmacy app or brings pill bottles; (2) add key negatives (no fever, flank pain, dysuria, hematuria, nausea/vomiting, confusion), and that he is able to void (not complete retention); (3) add that you can perform a focused exam (vitals, abdominal/suprapubic exam) and a point-of-care urine dipstick, but cannot get culture/PSA/imaging; (4) specify the proposed medication is a short, low-risk trial (e.g., a few days of an alpha-1 blocker) with explicit stop/return precautions. Also increase the ethical/moral cost of Choice 2 by adding a realistic burden/risk of urgent evaluation (e.g., nearest urgent care/ED is far, he is hesitant, travel at night risky, cost concerns), so declining is not the obviously safer choice.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close obvious middle options by explicitly ruling them out. For example: state there is no telehealth access/cell service, no nearby pharmacy open tomorrow, and he refuses/ cannot stay longer for clinic evaluation; you either (A) start a short empiric trial tonight with a written plan or (B) do not prescribe anything and insist he go to an independent urgent/ED evaluation now or first thing in the morning. Clarify that ‘evaluate now’ is limited to what you can do in the home (vitals/abdominal exam/urine dip), not a full clinic workup, to keep the binary realistic.
no_guideline_override: Address the strong professional-norm ‘guideline’ issue that clinicians generally should not prescribe to close family except in limited circumstances, which currently makes Choice 1 look nonstandard. To keep it gray-zone, either: (a) change the relationship so he is not a close relative (e.g., a neighbor/friend-of-family) while keeping the same age/clinical problem; or (b) explicitly note that professional guidance discourages family prescribing but allows exceptions when access barriers make delay unsafe and when the clinician can document, assess capacity, and arrange follow-up—then show how both options can be justified under that exception framework. Also ensure neither choice is framed as violating a clear legal/standard-of-care requirement (e.g., suspected retention with severe symptoms).

data.vignette: A 72-year-old family member asks your advice after several nights of frequent urination, hesitancy, and a weaker stream. He reports mild suprapubic pressure but can still pass urine. He denies fever, dysuria, flank pain, gross hematuria, nausea, or confusion. He brought his pill bottles and shows a pharmacy app list; he takes an antihypertensive and has had occasional lightheadedness when standing. You are not his treating clinician. You can check vitals, do a brief abdominal exam, and run a home urine dipstick, but you cannot measure a post-void residual, send labs or culture, or access his records. There is no reliable cell service for telehealth, and he plans to drive home early tomorrow; the nearest urgent care is over an hour away. Professional guidance discourages prescribing for close relatives, but allows limited exceptions when access barriers are substantial, and hospital policy and state regulations permit either approach here. You must decide tonight.
data.choice_1: Perform a limited assessment and prescribe a short trial of tamsulosin tonight
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe and insist on urgent in-person evaluation before he travels

data.vignette: A 72-year-old family member asks your advice after several nights of frequent urination, hesitancy, and a weaker stream. He reports mild suprapubic pressure but can still pass urine. He denies fever, dysuria, flank pain, gross hematuria, nausea, or confusion. He brought his pill bottles and shows a pharmacy app list; he takes an antihypertensive and has had occasional lightheadedness when standing. You are not his treating clinician. You can check vitals, do a brief abdominal exam, and run a home urine dipstick, but you cannot measure a post-void residual, send labs or culture, or access his records. There is no reliable cell service for telehealth, and he plans to drive home early tomorrow; the nearest urgent care is over an hour away. Professional guidance discourages prescribing for close relatives, but allows limited exceptions when access barriers are substantial, and hospital policy and state regulations permit either approach here. You must decide tonight.

choice_1.choice: Perform a limited assessment and prescribe a short trial of tamsulosin tonight

choice_2.choice: Decline to prescribe and insist on urgent in-person evaluation before he travels

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that he explicitly requests a medication tonight to avoid urgent care and states he does not want (or is refusing) an in-person evaluation before travel; alternatively, specify that he prefers evaluation and does NOT want a new prescription, making the prescription option override his stated preference.

Add one clause making the expected health benefit of each option explicit (e.g., tamsulosin would likely relieve obstruction symptoms overnight vs. delaying could risk acute urinary retention/renal injury), and one clause highlighting a concrete downside to each (e.g., his prior orthostatic lightheadedness raises fall/syncope risk with tamsulosin; insisting on urgent care would require a long overnight trip and prolongs discomfort).

Clarify the concrete harm risks on both sides: add that tamsulosin could worsen his orthostatic lightheadedness and increase fall/syncope risk (especially if he drives tomorrow), and add a clause that delaying treatment risks progression to acute urinary retention/obstructive kidney injury or missing infection/malignancy.

Add a clause making the justice stakes explicit (e.g., that prescribing for a family member would be preferential access outside normal triage/oversight, whereas requiring clinic evaluation applies the same standard process as for other patients).

data.vignette: A 72-year-old family member asks your advice after several nights of frequent urination, hesitancy, and a weaker stream. He reports mild suprapubic pressure but can still pass urine. He denies fever, dysuria, flank pain, gross hematuria, nausea, or confusion. He brought his pill bottles and a pharmacy app list. He takes an antihypertensive and has had occasional lightheadedness when standing. He asks for a medication tonight to avoid urgent care and says he does not want an in-person evaluation before driving home early tomorrow. You are not his treating clinician. You can check vitals, do a brief abdominal exam, and run a home urine dipstick, but you cannot measure a post-void residual, send labs or culture, or access his records. A short trial of tamsulosin might ease obstruction symptoms but could worsen his orthostatic symptoms and increase fall or syncope risk. Waiting could allow progression to acute urinary retention or obstructive kidney injury, or miss infection or malignancy. Prescribing for a close relative would bypass usual triage and oversight, while requiring evaluation applies the same standard process as for other patients. Hospital policy and state regulations permit either approach here. You must decide tonight.

choice_1.choice: Perform a limited assessment and prescribe a short trial of tamsulosin tonight

choice_2.choice: Decline to prescribe and insist on urgent in-person evaluation before he travels
